text: "Because they're sitting still all day long they start to get restless and start tapping their desks and their feet are moving about," she said. "They're not doing it to be defiant - it's just about being able to move. "Ms Lambeth used to teach at a primary school where she says the children did more PE and always had more energy than the 11 to 14-year-olds she currently teaches.Inspired by an article she had read about primary pupils using bicycle pedals under the desks in a reading class she decided to try it herself. "I didn't tell the students what they were for but just put them under the desks and said 'see what you think of this'," she said. "There are 10 bike pedals and 14 desks so they don't have to use them. They are silent and kids can change the tension so if they feel they have more energy they can crank up the tension. "Within a week some students started to say they thought they were focusing more and Ms Lambeth noticed that they were more engaged in conversation in class. "They were able to recall a lot more of what I was saying and because they participated more they understood more and they did better in tests. "As a result she says their test grades demonstrably improved from when the pedals were introduced in April compared to earlier in the school year.Other teachers using the same classroom have also noticed an improvement in students' grades and parents have reported that their children were more interested in just being in the class.The pedals cost $180 (Â£138) each and were bought with a grant from the local Wake County Public School System.Now the school is hoping to buy more pedals and extend the programme.Staff who work with youngsters on the behavioural support programme area are also interested in seeing if they can make a difference for them.By Annie Flury, UGC and Social News team.

text: under-desk bike pedals.What started as an observation—that her students were constantly moving about and struggling to concentrate—led Lambeth to think outside the box. In an effort to channel her students' excess energy, she decided to install small exercise machines under their desks."My students were always fidgeting and seemed unable to stay still, which made it difficult for them to concentrate on their work," Lambeth explained. "I wanted to find a way to help them release that energy without disrupting the class."The pedals, small and unobtrusive, provide a way for students to engage in low-intensity physical activity during lessons. Surprisingly, the addition did more than just keep the students occupied; it also appeared to have a positive impact on their academic performance."After a few weeks, I noticed a significant improvement in my students' ability to concentrate," Lambeth reported. "They were calmer, more focused, and their grades started to improve."The new classroom dynamic turned out to be particularly beneficial for students with attention difficulties. Being able to pedal during lessons helped them channel their restlessness into productive energy.One student, Nathan, shared his experience: "I used to get really antsy during class and had a hard time sitting still, but pedaling helps me focus on my work. I actually feel more relaxed."The results have been so promising that other teachers at Martin Middle School are considering adopting the same approach. Principal Sarah McNair expressed her support for Lambeth's innovative teaching method."It's exciting to see such a simple idea making a big difference," McNair said. "We're always looking for ways to improve student engagement and learning outcomes, and this could be just the thing we need."Lambeth hopes her experiment will inspire other educators to explore creative solutions to common classroom challenges. In the meantime, Martin Middle School students are pedaling their way to success, one lesson at a time.As more schools and educators learn about the benefits of movement and physical activity in the classroom, the simple addition of under-desk bike pedals could potentially become a widespread practice—a testament to how innovative thinking can transform education.

text: These included keeping schedules of cleaning regimes and detailed records of staff performance reviews. The Royal College of GPs also spoke out against the inspection system. Delegates at the BMA conference, in Liverpool, voted in favour of a motion saying the current Care Quality Commission regime was "unfit for purpose." The inspection regime, which began last year, will see all 8,000 practices in England given a rating by September 2016.### Growing Discontent Among Health ProfessionalsThe motion passed by the BMA highlights the growing discontent among health professionals regarding the current inspection protocols. Dr. John Smith, a GP from Manchester, commented, "These additional tasks divert our focus from patient care and add unnecessary pressure to an already overstretched system."### Critical Response from the Royal College of GPsThe Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) has echoed these concerns. Dr. Helen Stokes-Lampard, Chair of the RCGP, described the inspection process as "bureaucratic and counterproductive." She emphasized that the primary aim should be to enhance patient care rather than burden practices with excessive administrative tasks.### The Care Quality Commission's StanceIn response to the criticism, the Care Quality Commission (CQC) acknowledged the feedback but defended the inspection regime. A spokesperson for the CQC stated, "Our goal is to ensure that patients receive the highest quality of care. While we recognize the concerns raised by healthcare professionals, we believe that thorough inspections are essential to uphold these standards."### Implications for the FutureThe debate over the current inspection regime could lead to significant changes in how healthcare practices are evaluated in the future. With healthcare professionals calling for a more streamlined and patient-focused approach, it remains to be seen whether the CQC will make adjustments to their protocols.### ConclusionAs the CQC moves towards completing its assessments of all practices by September 2016, the ongoing dialogue between the organization and healthcare providers will be crucial.

text: "One of the things we found was it's actually very easy to see bubbles forming in stout beer rather than in, say, champagne where the bubble formation process is much more violent," Dr Lee told BBC News.But as has happened to a generation of like-minded scientists before them, the question of falling bubbles became their focus.The team had the idea - borne out by calculations carried out by Mr Cummins - that the relative density of bubbles and the surrounding liquid could be behind the phenomenon. "If you imagine your pint is full of bubbles, then the bubbles will start to rise," Dr Lee said.But the bubbles in a standard pint glass find themselves in a different environment as they rise straight up. "Because of the sloping wall of the pint, the bubbles are moving away from the wall, which means you're getting a much denser region next to the wall," Dr Lee explained. "That is going to sink under its own gravity, because it's less buoyant, and that sinking fluid will pull the bubbles down. "The bubbles, that is, are "trying" to rise, but the circulation that creates drives fluid down at the wall of the glass. "You'll see sinking bubbles not because the bubbles themselves are sinking, but because the fluid is and it's pulling them down with it. "The same flow pattern occurs with other beers such as lagers, but the larger bubbles of carbon dioxide are less subject to that drag.Mr Cummins carried out calculations using a simulated pint and "anti-pint" - that is, the upside-down version of a pint glass - showing the effect at work; in the anti-pint, the bubbles rise as expected.For those interested in experimenting in the pub, the effect can be best seen if a pint of stout is served in a straight-sided, cylindrical glass (not quite filled up).If the glass is tilted at an angle while the pint settles, the side in the direction of the tilt represents the normal situation of a pint glass, while the opposite side is the "anti-pint" - and bubbles can be seen to both rise and fall in the same glass.

text: The Future of the Controversial Detention Facility#### Background and Recent DevelopmentsThe Pentagon’s recent transfer of 12 Yemeni nationals and three Afghans has reduced the number of detainees at the Guantanamo Bay detention facility to 61. Opened in January 2002 by former President George W. Bush in the wake of the 11 September attacks and the subsequent US-led invasion of Afghanistan, the prison was established to detain foreign terror suspects. To date, 779 men have been held at Guantanamo, which peaked at 684 detainees in June 2003.President Obama has been vocal about his intent to close Guantanamo before the end of his term, arguing that the facility damages U.S. relationships with key international partners critical in combating terrorism. Additionally, he contends that Guantanamo Bay undermines U.S. values and weakens the nation’s global standing, which is based on adherence to the rule of law. With most inmates held without charges and Obama himself lamenting in February that "not a single verdict has been reached" for those with charges, the prison's operation poses significant human rights issues.#### The Case Against Guantanamo BayThe president argues that Guantanamo Bay is a recruitment tool for jihadists and maintains that it is prohibitively expensive to run, costing $445 million annually. Furthermore, 20 of the remaining detainees are already approved for transfer, leaving 34 in continued detention and 7 facing criminal charges.However, Obama’s ambition to close the facility faces significant hurdles, primarily due to required congressional approval. With Republicans holding the majority in both houses, many in the party advocate for keeping the prison operational. Ed Royce, the Republican chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, criticized the latest inmate releases, stating: "Once again, hardened terrorists are being released to foreign countries where they will be a threat."#### Congressional ResistanceCongressional reluctance to close Guantanamo stems from concerns about national security risks. Many lawmakers fear that released inmates could return to terrorist activities. This stance is bolstered by cases where former detainees have re-engaged in hostile activities post-release, although the exact recidivism rate remains a contentious topic among analysts and policy experts.#### The Path ForwardWith only a few months left in President Obama's administration, the outlook for closing Guantanamo Bay remains uncertain. Securing congressional approval to fully shut down the facility appears increasingly unlikely, particularly with firm Republican opposition. Nevertheless, Obama might explore alternative executive actions to reduce the detainee population further.Looking beyond Obama's term, the future of Guantanamo Bay will largely depend on the incoming administration's policies and the balance of power in Congress.

Parkinson's side looked disjointed and unable to capitalize on their offensive options.**Oxford's Tactical Edge**The first half offered little excitement, with Oxford slightly edging the play. Mark Howard was called into action early on, scrambling to parry a shot from Maguire, signaling the visitors' intent. Bolton's brief moment of promise came soon after the interval when Charlie Raglan nearly put into his own net from a Zach Clough cross, only to narrowly clear the danger.However, as the game progressed, Oxford began to assert their dominance. Kane Hemmings had a solid effort saved by Howard, who was soon called into action again to deny substitute Alex MacDonald.**Late Drama Secures Victory**The breakthrough came in the 81st minute when Thomas scored, becoming the first player other than Hemmings to net an away goal for Oxford this season. As Bolton pushed forward in search of an equalizer, Oxford capitalized on the gaps left at the back. In the closing moments of the match, Maguire sealed the victory, scoring into an empty net after Howard parried away another fierce shot from Hemmings.**Final Whistle**The final whistle confirmed a significant victory for Oxford United, who will hope this performance can act as a springboard for further success in the higher division. Conversely, Bolton Wanderers face increasing pressure to turn their form around and find the back of the net.**Match Highlights:**- **81' Goal**: Thomas (Oxford)- **90'+ Goal**: Maguire (Oxford)**Final Score: Bolton Wanderers 0, Oxford United 2** **Post-Match Reactions****Karl Robinson (Oxford United Manager):** "This win is massive for us. We've been working hard on our defensive structure and today it paid off. The lads showed immense character and discipline. It's not easy to come to a place like Bolton and get a result, but we did it with style. I'm proud of every single one of them."**Phil Parkinson (Bolton Wanderers Manager):** "We're gutted.

text: according to the Financial Times.One former special adviser, who worked in Downing Street and the Cabinet Office at different times, told the BBC the three month deletion policy sometimes caused chaos, particularly when dealing with other departments who had less strict deletion regimes. "You would just constantly lose stuff and you had to make sure you had a decent record saved," he told BBC News, on condition of anonymity.Policy documents could be saved but "you wouldn't be able to save e-mail conversations or anything like that," he added.He said he always got the impression that deleted material was being held on "back-up" servers. "I am sure that there were ways if you needed to retrieve then you could," he said, but added that it rarely happened in practice. "When an FOI request came in you were asked by whoever was responsible to do a search in your in-box for anything that is current," he added.The Cabinet Office had what seemed like "weird" security protocols, such as preventing staff from "cutting and pasting" from websites, he added.Another former official, at a different department, said officials complying with FOI requests asked staff to trawl inboxes but never looked at back-up servers.But he added, copies of e-mail conversations held by other people meant that it would be difficult for anyone to cover their tracks if they had something to hide - and he was not aware of any minister or official deliberately deleting material to avoid FOI.The Cabinet Office began deleting all e-mails after three months in 2004.The reason for this, it said, was to comply with a request from the National Archive, which is responsible for storing records of government decision making, such as minutes of meetings and policy notes.A Cabinet Office spokesman said: "Keeping essential emails and deleting less significant messages like diary alerts, actually makes it easier to run searches and respond to FOI requests. "This is in line with the civil service code and guidance from The National Archives. "But Maurice Frankel, of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, accused the Cabinet Office of trying to get round FOI legislation. "The government always says the purpose of this is to improve record management. "But the policy was timed to coincide with the introduction of the Freedom of Information Act. "It is a matter of interpretation as to whether this is an attempt to make sure potentially embarrassing material is not available in the future or whether it is entirely coincidental."

text: The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) is designed to provide the public with access to governmental documents that offer insight into decision-making processes. But with a system that routinely erases communications within a short timeframe, the effectiveness of the FOIA is significantly undermined.Journalists, researchers, and political watchdogs express concerns that crucial information which could shed light on policy discussions and government actions may be permanently lost. Without access to these records, it becomes exceedingly difficult to fact-check official narratives, investigate potential misconduct, or hold public officials accountable for their decisions.The policy has also sparked a debate about the balance between operational efficiency and historical preservation. While proponents argue that automatic deletions help manage digital clutter and streamline governmental operations, opponents warn that the loss of records can disrupt the continuity of knowledge, making it harder for successive administrations and civil servants to learn from past events and decisions.There's also the question of technological feasibility. Critics insist that modern data management systems could easily archive essential communications without overwhelming storage capacities or budgets. They point out that, in an era where data can be stored cheaply and efficiently, the three-month deletion window seems both arbitrary and unnecessarily restrictive.Ultimately, the controversy underscores a broader discussion about transparency in governance. As digital communication becomes increasingly central to governmental operations, policies governing the preservation and accessibility of this data will play a crucial role in shaping public trust and accountability. Advocates for reform are calling for updated guidelines that balance operational needs with the public’s right to know, ensuring that the spirit of the FOIA is honored in the digital age. ### Demand for Reform and Legislative ActionThe growing discontent among journalists, researchers, and political watchdogs has reached the halls of Congress. Several lawmakers have introduced legislation aimed at reforming the current policies surrounding the retention and deletion of digital communications. These legislative proposals seek to extend the retention periods, enhance the capabilities of archival systems, and establish clearer guidelines on what constitutes essential records that must be preserved.One such bill, the "Digital Communications Preservation Act," proposes extending the retention window from three months to three years, arguing that a longer timeframe is vital for transparency and historical accuracy. The bill also mandates the implementation of advanced archival technologies that can store large volumes of data securely and cost-effectively. Supporters of the bill believe that such measures will ensure that critical communications are not lost, thus maintaining a comprehensive historical record.### Public Involvement and AdvocacyThe drive for reform is not limited to the legislative arena.
label: llm

"It's almost like a vanishing twin, or sometimes called a parasitic twin," he said. "I have actually seen a case of the foetus being attached to the outside of the living twin, so it's possible for the twin to be both inside or outside the body. "There have also been cases of two twins found inside the abdomen of one child, in the case of a triplet pregnancy.What causes it?There is no known trigger, but it occurs in the early stages of development when one foetus wraps around the other.The enveloped twin then does not fully form but becomes a "parasite", relying on their host twin for their survival. Such twins usually die before birth.The abnormality is estimated to occur in 1 in 500,000 live births.Is it unusual to live so long with the twin?One widely reported case was of a 36-year-old man in India whose tumour had grown so big that he was having difficulty breathing.In villages or smaller towns where access to medical facilities are limited, it is possible for someone to not know they have a foetus and live with it their entire life, says Dr Raman.The abnormality is easily spotted if a baby undergoes an ultrasound or CT scan, and there have been cases of babies as young as three months old being operated on.

text: It's a word that gets bandied around so much, and so often, it runs the risk of becoming meaningless.It's worth remembering, though, that only 12 months ago the #OscarsSoWhite controversy was all Hollywood was talking about.Two years of all-white line-ups in the four acting categories stung the Academy into taking concerted measures to broaden its membership's make-up.Viewed in that light, this year's list of award winners makes for much more encouraging reading.Yet it wasn't just the winners who reflected the "identity rainbow" Jodie Foster spoke about at a pre-Oscars rally.From Loving's Ruth Negga to Moonlight's Naomie Harris to Lion's Dev Patel, the losers were a pretty diverse bunch too.Auli'i Cravalho, an actress of Chinese, Irish, Native Hawaiian, Portuguese and Puerto Rican descent, sang a song on stage.And Lion's Sunny Pawar, an eight-year-old boy who was born and raised in a Mumbai slum, got lifted aloft by Jimmy Kimmel, the ceremony's host.Millions around the world were watching last night. President Trump, however, is not thought to be among them.Yet that didn't spare him a ribbing from Kimmel, or from being taken to task both obliquely and directly.Asghar Farhadi, the Iranian director of best foreign film The Salesman, stayed away in protest at the Trump administration's travel ban on immigrants.In his absence, a speech was read out that castigated the "inhumane" legislation for disrespecting his homeland and the six other countries it targeted.There were many moments to cherish at this year's Oscars - some humorous, some moving and some downright calamitous.Yet perhaps the most telling came when the stars of Hidden Figures arrived to announce the winner for best documentary feature.With them came Katherine Johnson, the 98-year-old African-American woman who was one of the real-life inspirations behind the space race drama.Could a woman born in 1918, who has lived through Jim Crow, segregation and the fight for civil rights, have ever dreamed of a day when her presence at the Oscars would generate a spontaneous standing ovation?La La Land may have won the most awards at this year's ceremony, but diversity was surely the biggest winner of all on Hollywood's glitziest night.Follow us on Facebook, on Twitter @BBCNewsEnts, or on Instagram at bbcnewsents. If you have a story suggestion email entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.

text: Amid reports that the UK could face a bill of between €34bn (£30bn) to €60bn (£52bn), Mr Barnier is saying the exact sum will be determined on the EU side by the EU's Court of Auditors towards the end of the two year negotiations.The ballpark in Brussels is that the EU has liabilities of around €600bn (£520bn). The UK would be responsible for around 12% of that, producing a rough figure of €60bn (£52bn).Former Finnish prime minister, Alex Stubb, who recently met Barnier, explained the thinking in Brussels to BBC Newsnight.Mr Stubb said: "Basically what's going to happen is that Article 50 is triggered and a few key principles will be agreed - say the principles of finance or the principles for EU citizens and British citizens in Europe - the big things. And then at the same time in parallel you can start negotiations on a  future relationship. "Mr Barnier is telling the UK that the main principle of the financial settlement is that the UK will have to honour the legal commitments it made as a full member of the EU.The key element will be the cohesion fund which is used to pay for infrastructure projects in deprived parts of the EU.This accounts for around a third of the EU budget which lasts until 31 December 2020. All cohesion funding has been agreed for the current seven year budget and the UK would be expected to honour the commitments it gave when the current seven year EU budget was agreed by David Cameron in 2013.The UK will not be responsible for its full share of the budget up until 2020 because the EU agrees on large parts of the seven year budget on an annual basis.Any commitments agreed once the UK has triggered Article 50 will not have to be funded by the UK.Mr Barnier will also table what are described as "standing commitments" in Brussels made by all member states.These cover two key areas:Nicholas Watt is political editor for BBC Newsnight

text: The first required principle involves the financial settlement, colloquially referred to as the "divorce bill," that the UK must pay upon leaving the EU. This settlement aims to cover the UK's share of commitments made while it was a member. The second principle concerns the rights and status of EU citizens residing in the UK, an issue of significant importance to the EU member states.Upon reaching an agreement on these principles, Barnier indicated a readiness to expand the negotiations to include a comprehensive range of issues, including the future relationship between the UK and the EU. This move is seen as a concession to the UK’s demand for parallel discussions on post-Brexit trade relations alongside the Article 50 exit negotiations.Prime Minister Theresa May plans to initiate the formal Brexit process by triggering Article 50, which sets a two-year deadline for departure negotiations, in the final week of March. This initiation will start the clock on a complex and highly scrutinized process, requiring both sides to resolve numerous contentious issues within a relatively brief window.The financial settlement amount, often estimated to be in the tens of billions of euros, remains a contentious point and will be negotiated in detail later in the process. This step-by-step approach, starting with principles before specific figures, aims to build trust and create a foundation for more in-depth discussions on future UK-EU relations.**Key points:**- The UK must agree on two primary principles: the financial settlement and the status of EU citizens in the UK.- Michel Barnier is prepared to discuss the broader UK-EU relationship after these principles are settled.- Theresa May will trigger Article 50 by the end of March, commencing a two-year negotiation period for Brexit.- The exact "divorce bill" will be determined later in the negotiation process.As the UK moves closer to formalizing its exit from the EU, all eyes will be on how both parties navigate these initial agreements and shape the future of their economic and political relationship.

text: "The challenge is to explain the origin of the volatile elements like carbon that remain outside the core in the mantle portion of our planet," said Rajdeep Dasgupta, a co-author of the study from Rice University in Houston, Texas.According to a widely accepted idea called the Late Veneer Hypothesis, Earth formed from material that was largely devoid of volatiles. These elements, such as carbon, sulphur, nitrogen and hydrogen, were added later on by space rocks after Earth's core had finished forming. "Any of those elements that fell to Earth in meteorites and comets more than about 100 million years after the Solar System formed could have avoided the intense heat of the magma ocean that covered Earth up to that point," said Yuan Li, from the Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry at the Chinese Academy of Sciences. "The problem with that idea is that while it can account for the abundance of many of these elements, there are no known meteorites that would produce the ratio of volatile elements in the silicate portion of our planet. "The group had previously published papers showing that if even if carbon had not vaporised into space when the planet was largely molten, it would have ended up in the metallic core of our planet - because the iron-rich alloys there have a strong affinity for carbon.But if this is the case, where did the carbon in the mantle and biosphere come from?The team used laboratory experiments that can recreate the high-pressure and high-temperature conditions that exist deep inside Earth and other rocky planets.The found that one scenario that could reconcile the discrepancies in the carbon-to-sulphur ratio and carbon abundance was an embryonic planet like Mercury colliding with and being absorbed by Earth, early in its history. "Because it's a massive body, the dynamics could work in a way that the core of that planet would go directly to the core of our planet, and the carbon-rich mantle would mix with Earth's mantle," said Dr Dasgupta.

We're not planning to add a banner to our home page, but we'll participate in other ways." The spokesman would not elaborate on the form Twitter's protest would take.According to one of the protest organisers, Free Press, Reddit and Netflix will be joined by Mozilla, Kickstarter and Upworthy, as well as Automattic - which runs WordPress - Digg and Vimeo.Other online firms taking part will include Boing Boing, Thunderclap and Urban Dictionary, as well as Foursquare, Digg and Cheezburger. text: The potential repeal has raised concerns among tech companies, startups, and advocacy groups about the future of an open internet. Opponents of the repeal argue that without net neutrality, ISPs could prioritize their own content or that of partners, disadvantaging smaller competitors and limiting consumer choice. The issue has become a flashpoint in the broader debate over digital rights and the role of government in regulating the internet.The FCC is expected to make its decision in the coming months, and the outcome will likely lead to significant legal battles. text: The United Nations estimates that the illegal wildlife trade is worth billions of pounds each year. Despite ongoing efforts by enforcement agencies and campaigners to curb the slaughter of threatened species, the trade continues to grow at an alarming rate.### Resurgence in PoachingIn recent years, there has been a troubling resurgence in the poaching of threatened species, raising serious concerns about the long-term survival of iconic animals such as tigers and rhinos. Campaigners have pointed to the growing demand for protected animal body parts and products on the Chinese black market as one of the primary drivers of this illicit trade. A recent report by UK think-tank Chatham House highlighted that demand was rising at an "alarming rate."### Alarming StatisticsThe authors of the Chatham House report noted that activity in the illegal ivory trade had more than doubled since 2007, with ivory fetching a price of US $2,205 (£1,526) per kilogram in Beijing. Even more shocking, rhino horn was reaching prices as high as US $66,000 per kilogram, which is more than the price of gold or platinum. These high prices reflect the immense profitability of the trade and the consequent motivation for poachers and traffickers.### A Global Criminal ThreatCrime prevention agencies recognize the threat posed by criminal enterprises targeting wildlife, listing the global trade alongside other major illicit activities such as drugs, arms, and human trafficking. The complex networks and significant financial gains involved in the illegal wildlife trade necessitate innovative approaches to enforcement and awareness.### The Launch of Wildlife WitnessThe app, named Wildlife Witness, represents such an innovation. It was developed by the Taronga Conservation Society Australia in partnership with Traffic, the wildlife trade monitoring network. Initially focused on the South East Asia region—recognized as a major hub in the global illegal wildlife trade—the app has now expanded its reach.### Raising Awareness GloballyIn this expansion phase, notable institutions such as Chester Zoo in Europe and San Diego Zoo in the United States are spearheading efforts to raise awareness of the project.

text: Once in each orbit, our satellite is totally illuminated - a full moon.And as the Moon orbits the Earth every 27 days or so, it travels in an elliptical or oval shape.This means that its distance from our planet is not constant but varies across a full orbit.But within this uneven orbit there are further variations caused by the Earth's movements around the Sun.These mean that the perigee - the closest approach - and full moon are not always in sync.But occasions when the perigee and full moon coincide have become known in popular parlance as supermoons.Taking good photos of the "supermoon"Prof Tim O'Brien from the University of Manchester advises skywatchers to look to the east, where the Moon rises, for the best view. Go somewhere with a low horizon, away from obstructions like tall buildings.He says there is an optical illusion when the Moon is low on the horizon that makes it look bigger.For the perfect snap, Nasa photographer Bill Ingalls suggests using a reference point: "Don't make the mistake of photographing the Moon by itself with no reference to anything," he says.He also advises scouting locations a day or two in advance and, if you are using a digital SLR, using a daylight white balance setting to capture moonlight.Supermoon photography (Nasa)To observers, the differences between a supermoon and a normal full moon are quite subtle.Generally, supermoons can be up to 14% larger and 30% brighter, but only when compared with the furthest point the Moon gets to within its orbit. "These differences are pretty small, and with the Moon rising so high in the sky, as it does in the winter months, it'll be quite hard to notice any difference without comparing photographs," Dr Chris North told The Conversation website. "But regardless of how big and bright it looks, the Moon really is a beautiful object to look at. "However Neil de Grasse Tyson, director of the Hayden Planetarium in New York, has previously suggested the events are just a little bit over-hyped. "I don't know who first called it a supermoon," he told StarTalk radio. "I don't know, but if you have a 16-inch pizza, would you call that a super pizza compared with a 15-inch pizza? "Skywatchers in Australia were disappointed when thick clouds obscured their view of the Moon, which made a short-lived evening appearance.At Bondi Beach in Sydney, the Moon rose at around 19:07 AEDT (08:07 GMT). "It did not meet my expectations. It came out for about 30 seconds," said one onlooker, Michaela.Follow Paul on Twitter.

text: A supermoon occurs when the full moon coincides with the Moon's closest approach to Earth in its orbit, also known as perigee. This combination results in the Moon appearing significantly larger and brighter in the sky.While the allure of a supermoon attracts many skygazers, capturing the perfect image of this astronomical phenomenon can be challenging. For those hoping to photograph the supermoon, here are some top tips:### Top Tips to Photograph the Supermoon1. **Use a Telephoto Lens:** To fully capture the details of the supermoon, use a telephoto lens with a focal length of at least 200mm.2. **Stabilize Your Camera:** A tripod is essential to eliminate camera shake, allowing for crisp, clear images.3. **Manual Settings:** Switch your camera to manual mode to control focus, exposure, and ISO settings. Start with a lower ISO to reduce noise.4. **Shoot Early:** Start photographing just after moonrise or before moonset when the Moon is near the horizon for a more dramatic composition.5. **Incorporate Foreground Elements:** Including buildings, trees, or landscapes can provide context and scale, making your photos more interesting.Unfortunately, the UK's Met Office forecast indicates a likely overcast sky during the peak of the supermoon. However, the ever-changeable British weather means there still might be breaks in the cloud cover, offering glimpses of the lunar spectacle. Keep an eye on your local weather forecast and be ready to seize any opportunity for a clear view.### Looking AheadThe next chance for such a close encounter with the supermoon won't come until November 25, 2034. Until then, the Moon will continue to captivate observers with its regular phases and the occasional less pronounced perigee. Whether you're a seasoned astronomer or a casual stargazer, moments like these remind us of the beauty and complexity of our natural satellite.### In Other NewsIn unrelated news, a look into human stories showcases a range of fascinating narratives:- **The Man Who Created a Tiny Country He Can No Longer Enter:** Discover the intriguing tale of a micronation's founder barred from his own creation.- **The Model Who Set Up a Travel Firm After a Dare:** Learn how one individual's adventurous spirit and a simple challenge led to a thriving business in the travel industry.- **Walnut the Whippet's Last Walk:** A heartwarming story of a community coming together to support a beloved pet's final journey.As the Moon transitions through its phases and orbits away from this supermoon event, we can look forward to many more shared experiences and stories that bring us closer together.

This adjustment aims to ensure that the vehicle's seat belt system fits children more securely, reducing the risk of injury in the event of a crash.### Implications for Parents and GuardiansParents and guardians are advised to review the new guidelines and reassess the booster seats they are currently using for their children. text: One for Arthur Stuns in Grand National****Aintree, England** — One for Arthur emerged as the unexpected winner of the Grand National, marking a historic triumph for Scottish-trained horses. This remarkable victory is only the second in history for a Scottish-trained steed, the first since Rubstic's win in 1979. The result sent shockwaves through the betting world. Renowned bookmakers William Hill reported they took approximately £25 million in bets on the race. The horse, ridden expertly by jockey Derek Fox, displayed extraordinary stamina and skill over the challenging Aintree course. Trained by Lucinda Russell, One for Arthur's name now sits alongside other legends of the Grand National.Punters who placed their faith in the Scottish contender were rewarded handsomely, with spontaneous celebrations erupting in betting shops and homes across the country. text: The report, which scrutinized 1,211 apps, highlights significant concerns regarding privacy and data protection for users worldwide. Alarmingly, nearly one-third of these apps were found to be requesting an excessive amount of personal information, raising further questions about data practices and user privacy.#### Key Findings:1. **Lack of Transparency:** The majority of apps do not clearly communicate what personal data they are gathering from users and how this data will be utilized.2. **Excessive Data Requests:** Approximately 33% of the studied apps were requesting more personal information than necessary, potentially exposing users to greater privacy risks.The findings have received strong backing from the UK's Information Commissioner's Office (ICO). Steve Wood, Deputy Commissioner for Policy at ICO, expressed concern over these revelations, stating, "Transparency and accountability are fundamental principles of data protection. It is unacceptable for apps to collect information from users without clearly explaining what is being collected and why."#### ICO's Response:The ICO has urged app developers to improve their data privacy practices by adhering to the following guidelines:- **Clear Privacy Policies:** Ensure privacy policies are easily accessible and written in simple, understandable language.- **Justified Data Collection:** Collect only the data necessary for the core functionality of the app and have a clearly defined purpose for data collection.- **User Consent:** Obtain explicit consent from users before gathering personal data, ensuring users are fully aware of what they are consenting to.The GPEN report underscores the importance of greater transparency and accountability in the digital ecosystem. The findings serve as a stark reminder for app developers and companies to prioritize user privacy and comply with data protection regulations.#### Moving Forward:In light of these findings, users are advised to exercise caution when downloading and using mobile apps. It is recommended to:- **Review Permissions:** Always review the permissions requested by an app before installation.- **Read Privacy Policies:** Take the time to read the app’s privacy policy to understand what data is being collected and why.- **Limit Personal Information:** Only provide necessary information and be cautious about granting access to sensitive data.As privacy concerns continue to rise, both users and regulatory bodies are calling for more stringent measures to protect personal information in the digital age.

text: When emergency care demands escalate, hospital resources—such as operating theaters and staff—may need to be reallocated to address more immediate needs. This can result in the postponement or cancellation of elective surgeries, causing significant distress and uncertainty for patients awaiting these procedures. Delays in elective surgery not only impact patient well-being but can also lead to deteriorating health conditions that eventually require more intensive treatment, thereby adding further strain to the system.Additionally, the backlog of postponed elective surgeries accumulates over time, creating a growing number of pending cases that need to be managed. This situation exacerbates the workload for surgeons and other medical staff and can prolong recovery times for patients who must wait longer for their surgeries.The challenges facing emergency departments are multifaceted. Solutions require a holistic approach that includes improving the flow within hospitals, ensuring adequate staffing, and enhancing communication and coordination between hospital departments and community care services. Investing in preventative healthcare and community-based services can also alleviate some of the pressure by reducing the incidence of acute health problems that necessitate emergency care.A comprehensive strategy that addresses both the immediate and underlying issues is essential for creating a more resilient healthcare system. Ensuring that patients have timely access to appropriate care—whether in emergency settings or for planned procedures—will improve overall outcomes and help maintain the sustainability of the NHS. In light of these challenges, several key strategies can be implemented to improve the resilience of the healthcare system:1. **Optimizing Bed Management**: Efficiently managing hospital beds is crucial. This includes rapid discharge processes and timely transfers to appropriate care facilities, ensuring that beds are available for those in urgent need.2. **Utilizing Technology and Data Analytics**: Advanced data analytics can predict surges in emergency department visits, allowing for better preparation and staffing adjustments. Electronic health records (EHRs) facilitate seamless information sharing, enhancing coordination between different care providers.3. **Expanding Community Healthcare**: Strengthening primary and community healthcare services can reduce the burden on emergency departments. By providing robust support for chronic disease management and preventative care, the incidence of emergencies can be minimized.4. **Flexible Staffing Models**: Developing flexible staffing models that can adapt to varying demand levels is essential. This could include cross-training staff to handle multiple roles or employing a pool of rotational staff who can be allocated where they are most needed.5. **Promoting Health Education**: Public health campaigns can educate citizens on when to seek emergency care and encourage the use of alternative care sources, such as urgent care centers, for less critical issues.6. **Telemedicine Integration**: Telemedicine can alleviate pressure by providing remote consultations, reducing the need for in-person visits in non-critical situations.

text: Liberia's Path to RecoveryLiberia, a nation deeply shaped by its unique founding history and tumultuous past, stands at a crossroads as it attempts to rebuild and move forward. Founded by freed American and Caribbean slaves, Liberia is predominantly inhabited by indigenous Africans, with the descendants of the freed slaves making up approximately 5% of the population. The country's civil conflict, which claimed around 250,000 lives and displaced many thousands more, left a significant scar on its social and economic fabric.In the aftermath of the civil war, Liberia has faced widespread challenges, particularly in rebuilding its infrastructure. Today, major initiatives are underway to address severe shortages in essential services like electricity and running water. These efforts are critical, as reliable access to these resources is foundational for improving living conditions and stimulating economic growth.The Liberian government, with support from international organizations and donor countries, has launched extensive programs aimed at rehabilitating and expanding the electricity grid. One key project is the Mount Coffee Hydropower Plant, which has been revitalized to boost the nation's energy capacity significantly. Efforts are also being made to diversify energy sources, including solar and other renewable energies, to ensure a more resilient supply.Simultaneously, addressing the lack of running water is a high priority. Projects focusing on the reconstruction and development of water supply systems have been initiated across various regions. International partners like the World Bank and USAID are collaborating with local agencies to improve water infrastructure, ensuring more communities have access to clean, safe drinking water.As these infrastructural projects progress, attention is also being directed towards education and healthcare. Improved electricity and clean water systems are expected to facilitate better conditions for schools and hospitals, which are vital for the nation's long-term development. Educational initiatives aim to bridge the gap caused by years of disrupted schooling, while healthcare programs seek to rebuild the country's medical services and improve public health outcomes.Moreover, Liberia's journey towards sustainable development is also marked by efforts towards political stabilization and economic diversification. Strengthening democratic institutions and fostering an environment conducive to investment are seen as pivotal to achieving lasting peace and prosperity.The road ahead is indeed challenging, but the resilience of the Liberian people coupled with concerted national and international efforts provides a beacon of hope.

text: Like the VCR, for instance - first shown at CES way back in 1970. Who could have foreseen the impact that piece of technology would have on the world?And 11 years later, the CD was shown here before anywhere else.These days, you rarely see entirely new things at CES. And so the show's purpose has changed somewhat - shifting into an event that is as much about spotting momentum rather than new products.But perhaps somewhere in the vast halls of the Las Vegas Convention Centre we've seen this year's VCR - a technology that will have impact well beyond what we can predict.Attendees - some 170,000 of them - are now heading home. And there seems to be a general consensus that CES 2016 signalled a transition year, but not a revolutionary one. The big ideas - like virtual reality, reinventing the car, or home robotics - were promising but still half-baked, a bun in the metaphorical (smart) oven. "We're in an in-between phase, where categories like drones, virtual reality, and wearables are growing and advancing, but still have a long way to go," wrote Rachel Metz from MIT Tech Review.The New York Times' Farhad Manjoo described CES 2016 as an "awkward adolescence" for emerging technologies.And that's absolutely right. VR has yet to go mainstream. Drones are out there, but set to be locked in regulatory hassle for the next year at least. And wearables? Well, let's just say too many companies are still thinking about function before fashion.CES 2016 was like it is every year: Big, overwhelming, full of terrible ideas, wasted money and overhyped nonsense.Gone are the days where you find the "next big thing" at CES. But if the technology business is alive and well, CES is still very much its pulse.Until next time, Vegas...Follow Dave Lee on Twitter @DaveLeeBBCRead and watch all our coverage from CES.

text: 'Nothing Worse for an Athlete Than Having a Special Sporting Moment Ruined by Suspicion'**In the world of sports, few things can match the euphoria of achieving a career-defining moment. When you finally achieve that moment, the last thing you want is for it to be tainted by doubts and allegations."Hoy, who has six Olympic gold medals to his name, emphasized that the stringent measures to combat doping and ensure fairness are both necessary and welcome. However, he suggested that the growing climate of distrust can sometimes cast a shadow over even the cleanest of victories. "Of course, we must continue to fight against doping. Clean sport is what we all strive for," he continued. "But it's disheartening when every exceptional performance is immediately met with skepticism. It can detract from the joy of the achievement, not just for the athlete, but for the fans and the sport as a whole."The cyclist's remarks resonate loudly in an era where social media and instant communication amplify both praise and criticism to unprecedented levels. Hoy's insight offers a poignant reminder of the delicate balance between vigilance and vindictiveness in the pursuit of fair play."It comes down to respect," Hoy concluded. "Athletes deserve the benefit of the doubt unless proven otherwise. Let's celebrate remarkable feats and leave the investigations to the authorities. That's the only way we can truly honor the spirit of competition."Hoy's comments have sparked discussion within the sporting community, prompting athletes, fans, and officials alike to reconsider how we view contemporary sporting achievements and the narratives that surround them.

text: A Race Against Time****Worcester, UK** — The town is buzzing with excitement and intrigue after an anonymous woman stepped into Ambleside News with a potentially life-changing lottery ticket. However, the ticket, which holds the winning numbers, is presenting a challenge: its date and barcode are illegible. The news was confirmed by Natu Patel, the local newsagent who runs the Warndon-based store.Camelot, the National Lottery operator, verified on Friday that the winning ticket was indeed purchased in Worcester. They are now urging the ticket holder to come forward and send in the ticket within the stipulated 30-day period. A Camelot spokesperson emphasized the urgency:> "If anybody believes they have bought the ticket and think they may have lost it, or washed it in their jeans, or it's been stolen, they need to make a claim within 30 days."The identity of the woman remains unknown, and the situation has sparked a sense of urgency and anticipation in the local community. Residents are keenly aware of the narrow timeline within which the claim must be made. ### The Clock is TickingThe process for validating a damaged lottery ticket involves a thorough investigation by Camelot. The ticket holder needs to provide evidence of purchase and, if feasible, any parts of the ticket that remain legible. While these situations are not common, there are precedents where damaged tickets have been successfully validated.Camelot reassured potential claimants that every effort would be made to ascertain the authenticity of the filed claims. However, without the critical information that typically verifies a ticket—such as the date of purchase, the barcode, and legible numbers—the process can be significantly hindered.### Community ReactionsThe local community in Worcester has shown a mix of empathy and eagerness as news of the damaged ticket spreads. Friends, neighbors, and even casual acquaintances hope the anonymous woman can prove her ownership and claim her prize.Many are also speculating on the story behind the ticket's damage. Was it an accident? Did it go through the wash? Was it somehow damaged in a moment of negligence or misfortune? Each theory adds another layer of mystery to an already compelling story.### Moving ForwardFor the unnamed woman, the next steps involve reaching out to Camelot directly and following the necessary protocols to file a claim.
label: llm

"James Kewin, deputy chief executive of the Sixth Form Colleges Association, said: "Study programmes that combine BTec and A-level qualifications are becoming increasingly common and have proved to be a highly effective way of helping young people to progress to higher education and employment. "He said: "I have requested that the hearings take place in public and that they broadcast live like council and assembly meetings. I have absolutely nothing to hide. "I am also requesting that the matter be dealt with as a matter of urgency within the next few weeks, or be dealt with after May's election. "I think the ultimate aim of those involved is to prevent me from standing for election in May. There are serious vested interests in Cardiff who do not want me making decisions after May. "The ombudsman could have referred the matter to the standards committee of Cardiff council but a referral to the Adjudication Panel for Wales is more serious because the potential sanctions are more severe.As well as being an AM for South Wales Central, Mr McEvoy is a councillor for the Fairwater area of the city and a former deputy leader of the local authority.Any suspension would have major implications for his ability to stand in council elections in the spring.A Plaid Cymru spokeswoman said: "Neil is a hard working AM and councillor who always gives 100% for his constituents. "First Avenue became a focal point for mourners after Prince died in April, aged 57. Hundreds of fans brought traffic to a standstill as they gathered outside the club, laying wreaths and singing his songs.Prince first played there in 1981, and visited throughout his career. His most famous song, Purple Rain, was recorded live at the club and edited down from the original 11-minute performance for release.He later played warm-up shows for the Parade and Sign O The Times tours at the venue, last visiting for a late-night show in 2007. "Playing there was always important," said Revolution drummer Bobby Z in an interview shortly before Prince's death. "It became his marquee, and it still is today. "The Revolution first announced plans for a reunion in April. "We have decided after spending three or four days together now grieving over the loss of Prince that we would like to come out and do some shows," said guitarist Melvoin in a short video. "We want to let you know that we'll be there soon, so we want to let you know now. "The musicians served as Prince's backing band from 1979, although they weren't officially credited as The Revolution until the Purple Rain album.Prince abruptly terminated their career in 1986 - taking many of the members by surprise. Wendy and Lisa went on to have a moderately successful career as a pop duo, and now work as composers for television, with credits including Heroes, Nurse Jackie and Touch.Tickets for the reunion concert cost between $65 (Â£50) and $99 (Â£76). Dez Dickerson and Andre Cymone, who played with Prince at the start of his career, will also take part in the show. "I need this as much as you," wrote bassist Brown Mark on his Facebook page after the show was announced. "I have no closure, I have no peace and the void echoes loud in an empty space deep within. text: "In New Zealand, and I'm sure the same is true in Orkney, our native birds didn't grow up with any mammalian predators. text: Older adults remain in larger homes in rural or suburban areas, while younger individuals gravitate toward urban centers where opportunities for employment and education are more abundant.### Housing Market and Policy InfluencesDr. Angus Hanton, co-founder of the Intergenerational Foundation, stated:> "The housing market has failed to adapt to the demographic changes over the past few decades. This age-segregation has implications for community cohesion and intergenerational understanding.### Government's ResponseIn light of these findings, a government spokesperson stated:> "Housebuilding is an absolute priority. We are committed to increasing the supply of homes and ensuring that young people have more opportunities to live in areas with economic potential."Current government policies aim to redress the imbalance by accelerating housebuilding projects, particularly in areas with high demand. There are also initiatives to incentivize older adults to downsize, thereby freeing up larger homes for younger families.### Broader Impact on SocietyThe separation of generations can have significant societal impacts. Communities where different age groups intermingle tend to be more resilient and innovative. Lack of interaction between ages can lead to a decline in shared values and mutual understanding.The Intergenerational Foundation stresses that addressing the root causes of age-segregation — particularly housing — is pivotal. Bridging the generational divide requires coordinated efforts from policymakers, developers, and local communities to create a more inclusive society.### ConclusionAs England and Wales continue to navigate demographic changes, the push for solutions to ease housing constraints will be critical. These cases, he explained, indicate a potential link between maternal transmission of the Zika virus in utero and subsequent birth defects. “The evidence from Brazil is deeply concerning,” Dr. Frieden stated. “However, we must stress that the suspected link between the Zika virus and these birth defects is not yet definite."Brazil has reported over 4,000 cases of babies born with microcephaly—a condition characterized by abnormally small brains. Though the exact cause remains under investigation, the prevalence of Zika virus transmission from mother to child has raised significant alarms among health officials.Dr. Frieden emphasized that intensive research is currently underway to uncover more about the mosquito-borne virus. "Our scientific community is working tirelessly to understand the mechanisms of Zika transmission, its full impact on fetal development, and to expedite the development of a vaccine,” he assured. He cautioned, however, that the development of a safe and effective vaccine could still be years away.**Global Impact**The Zika virus, primarily spread by the Aedes aegypti mosquito, has rapidly become a global health issue since its outbreaks in South America. The virus has been linked to various neurological disorders and congenital abnormalities, prompting widespread fear and urgent calls for international cooperation and funding to combat its spread.**U.S. Response and Preparedness**In response to the threat, the CDC has ramped up efforts to inform the public and healthcare providers about the risks associated with Zika, particularly for pregnant women.

text: "It is nerve-wracking," one said to me, perhaps euphemistically.Here is the ecstasy and agony of what could happen next week.If Greeks vote "Yes" to the deal with creditors - pension cuts, VAT rises and all - just maybe the European Central Bank (ECB), whose governing council meets on Monday morning, will lift the ceiling a fraction on the provision of Emergency Liquidity Assistance (ELA).That might not permit banks to start operating as normal with immediate effect. But it could allow the 60-euro daily ceiling on withdrawals to be raised a bit and the total freeze on transfers abroad to be eased somewhat.And that might allow the Greek economy to be taken out of the deep freeze it has been in since banks were ordered to more-or-less close last Monday.But if Greeks vote "No", as the government wishes them to do, there would be zero chance of the ECB turning on the ELA tap again.And as I said a few days ago, a "No" vote might persuade the ECB to demand additional collateral from banks to cover the risk of losses on the 120bn euros in emergency lending it and the Bank of Greece have already provided.This would be very painful for the banks. Right now they have unencumbered assets sufficient to borrow an additional 17bn to 20bn euros from the Bank of Greece, if the ELA ceiling were lifted.But if the ECB decided these assets - such as loans to Greek companies - are intrinsically less valuable than it currently thinks, and imposed a bigger so-called haircut on these loans, that 17bn to 20bn of possible additional credit could shrink to zero or a negative number.Or to put this more clearly, rather than lending to banks, the Bank of Greece and ECB could start to demand some of their outstanding credit back. Which none of the banks are in any position to give.Greek banks would go from their current frozen state to totally and utterly crippled. Which would dash any chance of them providing the fuel to re-start the Greek economy.And that would create a vicious cycle of more of the loans they've made to businesses and households going bad. Which in turn would wreak further damage on the banks.So there is a heavy responsibility both on Greek voters and then the European Central Bank over the next 48 hours. They will decide whether the Greek financial system and Greek economy stands or falls.

text: From its early days as a military aerodrome to the bustling hub we see today, Edinburgh Airport has continually evolved to meet the demands of passengers and the aviation industry."### A Century of Growth and DevelopmentTo mark the centenary, the airport is hosting a series of special events, giveaways, and competitions aimed at local schoolchildren, fostering a sense of community and pride in the airport's rich history. In its early years as a civilian airport, starting in 1947, Edinburgh Airport saw modest traffic, with only about 7,000 passengers utilizing its services. This number stands in stark contrast to recent figures: last year alone, a record 11.1 million passengers passed through its terminals, highlighting the airport's significant role in Scottish and international travel.### Notable Milestones**1947** - Edinburgh Airport begins operations as a civilian airport.**1971** - The British Airports Authority (BAA) takes over ownership, initiating a series of major redevelopments.**1977** - The new terminal, designed by the renowned architect Sir Robert Matthew, is officially opened by the Queen.**2012** - Ownership changes hands from BAA to Global Infrastructure Partners, paving the way for further modernization and expansion.Keith McCloskey reflects on these changes, noting, "What was once referred to as a 'Cinderella airport' in the 1960s due to its rundown state has now become a crown jewel in Scotland's travel infrastructure."### Looking to the FutureAs Edinburgh Airport celebrates its 100th year, plans for future development continue to be a top priority. Officials are exploring options for expanding terminal facilities, improving infrastructure, and incorporating sustainable practices to accommodate the growing number of passengers while minimizing environmental impact.The airport's Chief Executive commented, "Our journey is far from over. As we celebrate our history, we are also looking forward to the next 100 years. Our goal is to continue providing excellent service to our passengers and to remain a key player in the global aviation industry."In conclusion, Edinburgh Airport's centenary not only marks a century of incredible growth and transformation but also sets the stage for future advancements that will further solidify its standing as Scotland's busiest and most vital airport.

text: The rebellion within his Syriza party, sparked by tough new austerity measures imposed by Greece's EU partners as part of the latest bailout package, has led to heightened uncertainty in the political landscape.### Political Turbulence Amid Economic StrainThe snap election, set to test Tsipras’s leadership and the unity of Syriza, comes at a critical time. The previous bailouts required Greece to implement severe austerity measures aimed at reducing its burgeoning debt. These measures, although necessary to secure financial assistance from the European Union and the International Monetary Fund, have resulted in widespread public discontent due to deep cuts in public spending and significant tax increases.### Challenges Ahead for Syriza and GreeceWith key figures within Syriza rebelling against these austerity conditions, Tsipras faces the challenge of uniting his party and convincing a weary electorate that further austerity is the path to economic recovery. The financial reforms, while aimed at stabilizing Greece's economy, have disproportionately impacted the middle and lower classes, leading to strikes, protests, and a strained social fabric.### The EU's StanceGreece’s EU partners have emphasized that continued financial support is contingent upon the implementation of these stringent economic reforms. The upcoming election, therefore, holds not just domestic but also international implications. European leaders are keenly observing the political developments, aware that the election outcome could influence Greece's commitment to the agreed-upon austerity measures and, consequently, its future within the Eurozone.### Looking AheadAs Greece prepares for the snap election, the stakes are high. The electorate’s decision will not only shape the future political trajectory of the country but also determine how Greece navigates its ongoing economic crisis. The world watches as Greeks head to the polls, hopeful that the nation can find a path to stability and growth amidst these turbulent times. ### Potential Outcomes and ImplicationsTsipras's decision to call a snap election can be seen as a strategic move to consolidate power and reaffirm his mandate amid the internal party dissent. Should he succeed in securing a strong majority, it could enable him to push forward with the controversial austerity measures needed to comply with the EU's bailout conditions. However, failure to unite Syriza or secure broad public support could result in a fragmented government, increasing Greece's political instability.#### The Opposition's RoleThe opposition parties, sensing an opportunity, are gearing up to present themselves as viable alternatives to the austerity-weary electorate. They argue that there are better strategies for achieving economic recovery that do not rely as heavily on austerity. Their campaigns are likely to focus on growth-oriented policies, social equity, and renegotiating bailout terms to ease the financial burden on ordinary citizens.#### Impact on the EconomyIn the midst of this political turmoil, Greece's economic performance remains under intense scrutiny.

text: In January, the CPI stood at 1.9%, maintaining the same rate in February. Meanwhile, the inflation rate measured by the Retail Prices Index (RPI) slightly decreased to 2.7% in February from 2.8% in January.#### Impact of Fuel Prices on InflationA significant factor in the reduction of the inflation rate has been the drop in fuel prices. Average petrol prices fell by 0.8p per litre from January to February, in stark contrast to a rise of 4p per litre during the same period last year. Similarly, diesel prices plummeted by 0.8p per litre, compared to an increase of 3.7p per litre the previous year.These falling fuel prices have contributed to keeping the CPI low, providing some relief to consumers and businesses alike.#### Wages and Inflation: Narrowing the GapThe decline in the inflation rate has positively impacted the wage-price gap. According to the latest ONS figures, average total earnings rose by 1.4% in the three months leading up to January, compared to the same period the previous year. Public sector workers saw a modest pay rise of 0.9%, while private sector pay growth was more robust at 1.7%. This private sector pay increase has effectively kept pace with the rise in prices, suggesting a healthier economic environment for many workers.#### Government ResponsePrime Minister David Cameron took to Twitter to highlight that the latest inflation figures bolster the government’s economic strategy. The alignment between wage growth and inflation suggests that the government’s efforts to stabilize the economy are bearing fruit, at least in part.### Analyzing the Influence of Inflation on Personal Finances**Is Inflation Making You Poorer?**The relationship between inflation and personal wealth is nuanced. While inflation generally erodes purchasing power, the current lower rate of inflation means that the increase in wages can more closely match the rise in prices. This alignment can alleviate some of the financial pressures on consumers, helping them maintain or even improve their standard of living.### Q&A: What is Inflation?Inflation is the rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services rises, eroding purchasing power over time.

According to McBride's account, Brown feared that once the public grasped the scale of the crisis, Britain could descend into chaos.McBride quotes Brown expressing his deep concerns: "We'd have to think: do we have curfews, do we put the Army on the streets, how do we get order back?" These words highlight the extreme measures Brown contemplated to maintain control and stability in the face of potentially widespread panic and disorder.The book provides a rare glimpse into the behind-the-scenes deliberations of the Labour government at the height of the global financial meltdown. McBride recalls that Brown was acutely aware of the fragile state of public confidence and the potential for societal breakdown if a sense of panic took hold. The former prime minister's fears extended to contemplating the deployment of military forces to restore and maintain order.Brown's administration faced unprecedented challenges as financial institutions teetered on the brink of collapse, leading to interventions such as bank bailouts and stimulus packages aimed at stabilizing the economy. The measures, while controversial, were deemed necessary to prevent a total economic meltdown.These revelations underscore the gravity of the situation during that period and the extent of the government's concern for public order. As more details emerge, the public gains a deeper understanding of the complexities and pressures faced by leaders in times of crisis. The release of these revelations has triggered varied responses from political commentators, historians, and the public alike. Some view Brown's considerations as a pragmatic approach to a worst-case scenario, while others criticize the notion of military intervention as an overreaction to the situation.### Political Reactions**Current Labour Leadership**  Labour leader Keir Starmer has defended Brown’s actions, noting that the pressure of the economic crisis required unprecedented contemplation to ensure the nation’s security. "Gordon Brown was operating under an immense load of responsibility. text: Every poll throughout the campaign put the Conservatives ahead - and that was indeed the result.The final polls were fairly accurate about the Conservative and Lib Dem shares. It was Labour where they were uniformly wrong. They also overestimated UKIP and the SNP.Survation were closest to the actual result. Kantar Public's numbers were also reasonably good.YouGov's final poll, like most of the others, seriously underestimated Labour. Prior to that, they had been suggesting a closer race. They also had a separate seat projection model which had been indicating a hung parliament. That had been met with a lot of scepticism but, with hindsight, was pretty accurate.In the final weeks of the campaign, the polls were often criticised for being "all over the place". It's true that they were pointing to very different outcomes.That variation clearly made it difficult to interpret what they were saying. It's surely better, though, that they had different numbers than that they were all wrong in exactly the same way. If you're looking for consistent accuracy then opinion polls are probably not for you.Pollsters are also sometimes accused of herding - deliberately manipulating their figures so they all say the same thing. That accusation can't be levelled at this election.In 2015 the polls went wrong because their samples were not representative of the electorate - they contained too many Labour voters. They also failed to estimate the difference in turnout rates between different age groups - they overestimated turnout among young voters.The pollsters who were furthest from the actual result this time were those, like ICM and ComRes, who had taken the strongest measures to try to rectify the problem from 2015. Survation made no significant changes to their methodology and came out on top.It looks as though the errors this time were caused, at least in part, by fighting the last war.We'll never know the exact figures for turnout among young voters - it's a secret ballot remember - but YouGov's post-election estimate puts it at 57% for 18-19 year olds and 59% for 20-24 year olds.That's lower than for older voters but considerably higher than estimates for young voters in 2015.We can also see that the places where the number of voters increased the most were generally those with young populations. The assumption made by some pollsters that young turnout would continue to under-perform was probably wrong.

text: A Shifting Landscape in British PoliticsAs the highly anticipated campaign drew to a close, the gap between the two dominant parties, Labour and Conservative, became increasingly narrow. Despite the pundits and final polls suggesting a more definitive lead for the Conservatives, the actual results painted a slightly more complex picture.## Poll Predictions vs. Election RealityThroughout the campaign, the Conservatives appeared to hold a more substantial lead according to most polls. However, election night unveiled a reality that diverged from those predictions. While the Conservatives did edge out Labour, the margin was slimmer than expected. The discrepancy led to a flurry of analysis and speculation about what might have caused the polling inaccuracies.## A Mixed Outcome for the ConservativesThe outcome wasn't an unmitigated disaster for the Conservative Party. Despite the tighter-than-expected race, they managed to retain a majority, allowing them to continue their legislative agenda without the need for coalition-building. However, the narrower victory serves as a signal that the electorate's preferences may be more fluid than previously thought, suggesting both challenges and opportunities ahead.## Labour's ResurgenceFor Labour, the results signaled a significant resurgence. Although they did not secure a majority, their performance improved considerably compared to previous elections. This resurgence can be attributed to effective campaigning, a focus on key issues like healthcare and the economy, and perhaps a reaction against overconfidence perceived in the Conservative camp.## The Implications Moving Forward1. **For the Conservatives:** The results highlight the necessity to recalibrate their strategy and perhaps address underlying issues that may have alienated some voters. The closer margin indicates that the public mandate is less robust than the party might have hoped for.2. **For Labour:** The election outcome is a cause for cautious optimism. Moving forward, Labour has a foundation to build upon, and their focus will likely be on strengthening their leadership and refining their policy propositions to convert narrow losses into future wins.3. **For Other Parties:** Smaller parties saw varied success, with some gaining new ground and others struggling to maintain relevance. Their role in the political landscape remains crucial, particularly when the major parties' dominance appears less absolute.## ConclusionThe election night results reflect the dynamic and somewhat unpredictable nature of current British politics. While the Conservatives emerged victorious, the narrow gap suggests a country wrestling with complex issues and diverse viewpoints. For both major parties, the takeaways are clear: there is work to be done, and the next few years will be pivotal in shaping their futures.

text: Kennington advised.### Potential Implications and Future DirectionsThe findings of the Cochrane review are noteworthy as they suggest a possible intervention for reducing severe asthma attacks, a significant concern for many patients and healthcare providers alike. Vitamin D's role in immune function has been the subject of extensive research, and its potential effects on conditions like asthma open new avenues for therapy.However, caution is emphasized. The studies involved relatively small sample sizes and were conducted predominantly on adults with mild to moderate asthma. The outcomes for children and those with more severe forms of asthma remain unclear. Thus, while the results are promising, they are not yet conclusive enough to change clinical practice guidelines.Professor Martineau and his team stress the importance of further research. They plan additional analyses, with results expected in the coming months. These future studies will aim to clarify vitamin D’s effects across different demographics and severity levels of asthma, which could eventually inform new treatment protocols.### General Advice on Vitamin D SupplementationPublic Health England has already recommended that everyone consider taking vitamin D supplements during the autumn and winter months. This recommendation stems from the need to maintain bone and muscle health during periods of low sunlight, which can lead to vitamin D deficiency. For the general population, a daily intake of 10 micrograms is advised, though the dosage used in asthma-related trials was notably higher, ranging from 25 to 50 micrograms per day.Considering the widespread management of asthma in the UK—where approximately 5.4 million individuals are affected—any potential improvement in treatment outcomes is significant. With 185 hospital admissions and three deaths due to asthma occurring each day, new therapeutic strategies are urgently needed.### Seeking Professional AdviceIndividuals currently being treated for asthma are encouraged to speak with their GPs or pharmacists before making any changes to their treatment plans, including the initiation of vitamin D supplementation. Personalized medical advice is crucial, especially considering the nuanced findings of the Cochrane review and the ongoing investigations into this potential therapeutic approach.### ConclusionIn conclusion, while the initial findings from the Cochrane review bring hope, the medical community awaits further evidence to establish concrete guidelines.
