text: Since then, ERT has undergone several major overhauls to keep up with fierce private competition.These efforts were not entirely successful, and a fall in the company's ratings in the mid-1990s triggered a long-running debate about its cost and efficiency.Eighty per cent of the company's funding came from a licence fee included in electricity bills, and some of it was sourced from advertising revenue.Many Greeks objected to funding ERT through the licence fee, claiming that the company was too unpopular and too expensive. The broadcaster was also criticised for its openly pro-government reporting, especially since the start of the financial crisis in 2009.At the time of closing, ERT operated three main TV channels and more than a dozen national and local radio stations. ERT World TV catered for the Greek diaspora across the globe.The company's programming included news as well as factual and entertainment programmes. It claimed to broadcast more highbrow programmes - such as world cinema and documentaries - compared to the generally more light-hearted entertainment offered by its privately-owned rivals.The company's audience share in 2013 was relatively low at below 20%, with most Greeks preferring commercial broadcasters.The government's surprise decision to shut down ERT was, however, met with fierce criticism from the public. Even though most agreed that a restructuring and cost-savings were required at the company, its immediate closure was branded "dictatorial" by some.While most Greeks will continue getting their news and entertainment from private TV and radio stations, those in the east and some islands - where signal coverage is poor - may have to rely on Turkish broadcasters across the border.BBC Monitoring reports and analyses news from TV, radio, web and print media around the world. For more reports from BBC Monitoring, click here. You can follow BBC Monitoring on Twitter and Facebook.

text: Greece's Broadcasting PioneerThe company's roots date back to the 1930s when the National Radio Foundation was established in Greece. Over the ensuing decades, ERT (Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation), as it later became known, evolved into a well-established national institution, gaining respect and significance among the Greek populace.### From Radio to TelevisionERT's foray into the world of television began in the 1960s, marking a new era in Greek broadcasting history. As the country's sole television broadcaster, ERT played a pivotal role in shaping the nation's media landscape. Its programming offered a variety of content, ranging from news and educational programs to entertainment and cultural shows, becoming an integral part of daily life in Greece.### The Rise of CompetitionThis monolithic presence continued unchallenged until the late 1980s, a period that witnessed significant media liberalization. In 1989, private television channels began to emerge, injecting fresh competition into the market and diversifying the options available to Greek viewers. The introduction of these channels transformed the broadcasting environment, prompting ERT to innovate and adapt to the changing media landscape.### Adapting to the Digital AgeThe turn of the century brought further changes with the advent of digital broadcasting. ERT expanded its services to include multiple digital channels and online streaming, securing its presence in the modern media sphere. Despite the competition, ERT has managed to retain a substantial audience through its commitment to quality content and its role as a public service broadcaster.### Challenges and ResilienceERT's journey has not been without challenges. Financial crises and political pressures have periodically tested the organization's resilience. Notably, in June 2013, the Greek government controversially shut down ERT, citing austerity measures, which led to nationwide protests and international condemnation. However, ERT's significance was reaffirmed when it was relaunched in June 2015, reclaiming its place in the hearts and minds of the Greek people.### Looking ForwardToday, ERT continues to be a cornerstone of Greece's media landscape.

text: Accrington Stanley 1, Barnet 0The match between Accrington Stanley and Barnet ended with a narrow 1-0 victory for the home side, largely due to a spectacular free-kick by Shay McCartan.#### First HalfGoalmouth action was limited in the early stages, with the first real chance coming in the 29th minute when Stanley defender Matty Pearson hit the crossbar following a well-delivered corner from Sean McConville. Barnet had to engage in some desperate defending to keep Stanley at bay; a notable instance came on the stroke of half-time when Michael Nelson blocked a goal-bound strike from McConville.Despite the defensive efforts, Barnet struggled to make an impact on the offensive end. Their first shot on target came in first-half stoppage time, but Mauro Vilhete's attempt was easily handled by Stanley's on-loan goalkeeper, Marek Rodak.#### Second HalfThe home side started the second half with clear intent. Forward Shay McCartan came close to scoring with a powerful shot from 30 yards that sailed narrowly over the bar. At the other end, Barnet's Jamal Campbell-Ryce had a chip that was comfortably saved by Rodak.The decisive moment of the match came in the 54th minute. After Billy Kee was fouled on the edge of the area, McCartan stepped up and fired a 20-yard free-kick into the top corner, leaving Barnet's goalkeeper with no chance.Barnet pushed for an equalizer in the closing stages. Their top scorer, John Akinde, should have levelled the score six minutes from time, but his unmarked header from 10 yards was blocked on the line. There was still time for more drama, as Stanley substitute Jordan Clark hit the woodwork, but ultimately, Barnet could not find a way through.In the dying minutes, Barnet earned a corner, but it ultimately led to nothing as Accrington Stanley held on for the win.#### Final WhistleThe match ended with Accrington Stanley securing a hard-fought 1-0 victory over Barnet. *Match report supplied by the Press Association.***Match ends: Accrington Stanley 1, Barnet 0.****Second Half ends: Accrington Stanley 1, Barnet 0.****Corner, Barnet.**

text: "I was on my way to the grocery store and she stopped me and said, 'I heard you sing,'" Hawkins recalled.Barbara Ann's sister, Rosa Lee Hawkins, soon joined them. The three later discovered they were cousins.The trio was almost known as the Meltones or Little Miss and the MuffetsBut they settled on the Dixie Cups name in 1964 after being discovered by producer and singer Joe Jones.Jones took them to New York where they recorded Chapel of Love, written by Spector, Jeff Barry and Ellie Greenwich.The band came up with the song's unique vocal arrangement on the spot. "When Ellie and Jeff first played Chapel for us, we looked at each other, like, 'You really want us to sing that like that?'" Hawkins told Rolling Stone. "They said, 'Well, how do you want to sing it?' So I said, 'Give us a minute. '"We went in the corner and started singing. We walked back to them and when we sang it the way it was recorded, they were just, 'Wow! That was awesome. '"The song peaked at number 22 in the UK and was later covered by the Beach Boys.The Dixie Cups released further successful records in 1964 and 1965, including You Should Have Seen the Way He Looked at Me, Little Bell and a cover of the New Orleans standard, Iko Iko.But when their record label went out of business, the band's recording career effectively ended.Johnson quit soon after citing management and health concerns, having suffered with sickle cell anaemia. "Because it was the early sixties, we went through a lot as far as race and a whole lot of other things," Hawkins said. "We had a manager who wasn't really in our corner, but there were a lot of good times. "Johnson occasionally rejoined the band for performances, including one at the 2010 New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival.She died of congestive heart failure in a New Orleans hospice on 3 October.The singer is survived by a sister, Ida, and a brother, Howard. A memorial is planned in New Orleans next week. "The world has lost a classy lady, who had a magnificent sense of humour, a radiating smile, and was truly one of the best people we know," wrote the Dixie Cups on their website.Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsEnts, on Instagram at bbcnewsents, or if you have a story suggestion email entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.

text: The Band That Dethroned the Beatles**The Dixie Cups, a trio formed in the vibrant city of New Orleans, made history in 1964 when their debut single, "Chapel of Love," famously knocked The Beatles' "Love Me Do" off the number one spot in the US charts.Co-written by the legendary Phil Spector, "Chapel of Love" wasn't just a fleeting success; it solidified its place in music history by selling over a million copies. The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame later recognized its impact by including it in their list of 500 Songs that Shaped Rock and Roll, underscoring its enduring influence on the genre.The origins of The Dixie Cups can be traced back to a high school talent show in New Orleans. It was here that the group's harmonizing magic began when Rosa Lee Hawkins invited her cousin, Barbara Ann Hawkins, to sing with her. Alongside Joan Marie Johnson, the trio captivated their audience, setting the stage for their future success.Their harmonious blend and catchy melodies captured the hearts of many, and their rise to fame marked a significant chapter in the rich tapestry of 1960s music. "Chapel of Love" continues to be celebrated for its infectious joy and timeless appeal, reflecting the spirit and sound of an era that reshaped the musical landscape. The success of "Chapel of Love" catapulted The Dixie Cups into the limelight, but their journey in the music industry didn’t stop there. Riding the wave of their initial triumph, the group released a series of follow-up hits that echoed their signature sound and cemented their reputation.Their subsequent singles, such as "People Say" and "You Should Have Seen the Way He Looked at Me," continued to showcase their vocal prowess and earned them a steadfast fanbase. The Dixie Cups' ability to blend doo-wop, R&B, and the burgeoning pop sounds of the 60s ensured their place in the playlists of American homes and dance halls alike.Despite the changing tides of the music industry and the evolving tastes of the audience, The Dixie Cups maintained their presence and influence. They demonstrated resilience and adaptability, attributes crucial for longevity in the fast-paced world of pop music. Their enduring legacy is also marked by their involvement in the civil rights movement, as their rise to fame paralleled a pivotal era of social change in the United States. As African American women, they broke barriers and paved the way for future generations of artists.In the years that followed their peak, The Dixie Cups' music saw revivals through various media.
